qas.question: In what year did the Polish government officially take over the administration in East Prussia?
How was the pre-war population in East Prussia referred to as?
How much did the Ukrainians make up in population as a percentage in East Prussia?
How many were expelled in Operation Vistula in 1947?
How many chose to emigrate to West Germany in the 1950s?
In what year was the Polish Commission for the Determination of Place Names established?
How many Lemkos were expelled in Operation Vistula?
How many Ukrainians were expelled in Operation Vistula?

context: Representatives of the Polish government officially took over the civilian administration of the southern part of East Prussia on 23 May <a0_0><b5_0>1945<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Subsequently Polish expatriates from Polish lands annexed by the Soviet Union as well as Ukrainians and Lemkos from southern Poland, expelled in Operation Vistula in 1947, were settled in the southern part of East Prussia, now the Polish Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship. In 1950 the Olsztyn Voivodeship counted <b3_0><b6_0>689,000<b6_0/><b3_0/> inhabitants, 22.6% of them coming from areas annexed by the Soviet Union, 10% Ukrainians, and <a2_0>18.5%<a2_0/> of them pre-war inhabitants. The remaining pre-war population was treated as <a1_0>Germanized Poles<a1_0/> and a policy of re-Polonization was pursued throughout the country Most of these "Autochthones" chose to emigrate to West Germany from the 1950s through 1970s (between 1970 and 1988 <b4_0><b7_0>55,227<b7_0/><b4_0/> persons from Warmia and Masuria moved to Western Germany). Local toponyms were Polonised by the Polish Commission for the Determination of Place Names.
